area_name: m. Crevice right, and Psycho Wall

content.description: Including for completeness sake; it's always been busy when I want to try it.  A classic Gunks "face" climb.
content.protection: Plenty and easy to place.  Bolted TR anchor.
content.location: Straight up face across from 1-800-Stick-It Arete; stay ten feet left of crack with tree.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: Possibly the best 5.8 in Peterskill; it has a little of everything - arete climbing, face climbing, off-width crack, and slightly-overhanging jug-bashing. It was also the first route in Peterskill to have bolts off which you can rappel.
content.protection:
More than adequate, although perhaps not as much as a person might like. Bolted TR/rappel anchor. Easy walk-off.

 If leading you may find a #4 cam useful.
content.location: Start right of the open book on small arch in face; follow to off-width, and continue to top.  FWIW, I tend to start on the arete of the open book, end up on the face at the base of the offwidth, and traverse slightly into the offwidth; different strokes, etc.

content.description:
Including for completeness sake. 

  This route isn't nearly as popular as it's twin, Psycho Crack Right, likely because the anchor is somewhat problematic while PCR has bolts.  Looks just as fun - give it a try!
content.protection: Unknown.  Gear-only anchor at top (or trees with static line and/or directionals).
content.location: Start in open book and go out to crack on left; follow up to tree and continue open book and crack system to top.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: On the face to the right of Psycho Crack Right, angling rightwards at the right-angling bulge/flakes at mid-height.  This is a wonderful,  demanding TR testpiece. Tough to read the correct sequence.  It's basically a direct line up to the bolt anchor.
Yet another arete line with challenging, creative moves needed.
content.protection: Easy to TR.  Bring Ballnuts or a tiny cam (black Alien perhaps) to lead it.
content.location: Climb the arete that marks the right edge of the Psycho Crack face.

content.description: As chimney routes go, this one's pretty neat. Likely hidden for years behind a large tree, which now lies in pieces at the base (cut by Park personnel).  A wild line with a "bottomless" horizontal section.  Update - the route does have history, as it turns out.  Rich Romano, Andrew Zalewski, and perhaps others climbed this route years ago.
content.protection: This is a spooky but wild route to lead.  Adequate gear is there but it is often placed from uncomfortable positions.  Fortunately it's possible to TR it with two ropes.  You want to lower one rope down through the ceiling crack from above and hang a second down the front to protect the finish (e.g. same anchor as for Psychadelic).
content.location: Follow the chimney (tight down low) to where it widens and you can crab crawl out to the west face, where an offwidth crack leads to the top.

content.description: Another Rawdon route that he "said" was 5.xx, but was actually much harder.  He told me after the fact that, perhaps, it's a bit reachy.
content.protection: Looks scarce, but available.  No bolts at the top, but you can put gear in a crack at the top as a directional and run the main anchor off the Yellow Wallpaper bolts.
content.location: Start on the right wall of the crevice, on top of the first large "boulder".  Climb discontinuous finger crack to the top.  The wall "behind" you is off.

content.description: This is the second best 5.9 at PK.  Bring your jamming skills.  Enter the chimney left of Yellow Wallpaper.  Keep walking until you get to a rock in the floor that lies at a 45 degree slant.  Look up to your right; you'll see a round bulge 10' up.  This route follows the prominent crack that shoots straight up through the bulge and the wall above.  Follow the crack past a couple scary wedged blocks until 10' below the top, make a couple steps to the right and fire through the steep juggy top-out (crux).
content.protection: Not really adequate - and a fall in the chimney would be bad.  Tricky TR anchor.

content.description: The sister crack to the left of Black Wallpaper.  Follow thin (tips) crack up to a rest alcove 10' below the top (5.10 to get this far).  Then swing out right and power up crimps to the top (crux).
content.protection: Pro inadequate for a lead IMO; the crack is there, but this isn't the place to take a whipper.  Some friable rock up high.
content.location: Same start as Black Wallpaper.  TR off trees with long static rope/webbing.

pathTokens: m. Crevice right, and Psycho Wall

content.description: Home to the best 5.8 route in Peterskill - as well as two sets of anchor bolts - this wall is frequently occupied.  This wall also boasts the ONLY set of anchor bolts capable of rappeling from; in fact, it's a favorite spot for guides to teach their clients how to rappel.
